summary: The document details the employment and payroll records of Merete Muff Rosen with the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), including her salary adjustments, termination, and the bureaucratic processes involved. It highlights the challenges she faced in securing security clearances due to her foreign birth and parentage, despite being recognized as a competent worker. The document also includes a personnel inquiry questioning her loyalty, with her supervisor defending her competence and loyalty.
key_findings: Merete Muff Rosen served as a researcher for the HSCA with fluctuating salaries during her employment.
Her termination was due to the inability to obtain required security clearances from the FBI and CIA, primarily because of her foreign birth and parentage.
The document showcases the procedural aspects of payroll and employment within the U.S. House of Representatives, emphasizing the necessity for approvals and certifications.
Despite a personnel inquiry casting doubt on her loyalty, her supervisor affirmed her competence and loyalty, attributing the clearance denial to her foreign background.
